Award.AwardTitle: CCF: Medium: Collaborative Research: SHF: Cascode: Supporting and Leveraging Voltage Stacking in Future Microprocessors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Power dissipation is increasingly becoming the central issue in almost all computing and communication systems from mobile devices to warehouse-scale systems. This project investigates a technology that can shave off at least a few percent of chip energy of all chips by targeting one particular aspect of power consumption that has not received as much attention as others: power delivery. In addition to the team of investigators, the project will involve graduate and undergraduate students, include members of underrepresented groups and will thus help enlarge the nation?s workforce in information technologies.

Today's chips operate at low voltages (about 1V) to reduce power consumption. However, delivering the power at low voltage is problematic. For instance, it results in more delivery loss (in the real world, electricity is transported at voltages thousands of times higher than that of the usage voltage). This project will be investigating a solution called the Cascode power delivery system, which stacks multiple planes of circuit to naturally increase the effective usage (and therefore delivery) voltage. This design is not only likely to bypass some fundamental problems with other means of increasing power delivery voltage (such as using on-chip voltage converters), but also to creates new architectural opportunities such as improved communication circuits with higher voltages and better capabilities to compensate variations in the fabrication process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Power dissipation is increasingly becoming the central issue in almost all computing and communication systems from mobile devices to warehouse-scale systems. Operating voltages of microprocessors have thus been aggressively lowered. Yet, higher voltages can actually be a useful mechanism to lower power consumptions. Our initial plan in this project has been to use higher voltage supply to lower the current supply. But we quickly realizes that a more practical ways of utilizing higher voltages is through the communication substrate where high voltages can more directly improve the performance of high-speed communication circuitry and in turn lower energy wastes due to processor idling when accessing remote components. Higher supply voltages are particularly helpful in pulse amplitude modulation (PAM) links since they allow higher signal-to-noise ratio and hence faster data rate. We developed a new hybrid PAM-4 driver supporting high supply voltages and acheiving better energy efficiency than conventional current- or voltage-mode designs. A number of state-of-the-art high-performance transmitters and receivers have been designed, prototyped, and tested. We also analyzed their impact on system level design for high-performance computing systems. In particular, our research led to important, novel conclusions concerning a new trend in system design: near-data processing (or NDP) systems. It is generally believed in the architecture community that data movement is energy intensive and thus processing data as close as possible to the source of data is desirable. Our analysis shows that data movement does not have to be energy intensive if only we use more advanced communication circuitry than being assumed. In fact, these high-performance communication circuits allow us to efficiently carry data across relatively long distance with almost negligible energy overheads. This in turn allows us much more design freedom in constructing NDP systems. For instance, we can avoid directly stacking memory dies on top of the compute substrate, thereby avoiding high leakage-induced energy loss. Our analysis thus serves as a foundation for continued exploration for more energy efficient computing systems that the society depends on. Beyond technical contributions, the project also allowed the investigators to improve course offerings and to engage with local school communities in educational activities.
